subject: Economics
title: Thorstein Veblen: The Theory of the Leisure Class
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Thorstein Veblen: The Theory of the Leisure Class.

hook.text: In 1899, an eccentric Norwegian-American professor explained why rich people buy useless expensive things.

buildup.text: Veblen argued the wealthy don't just buy utility â€” they buy status.

discovery.text: He identified 'Veblen goods' â€” products that sell more at higher prices because the high price IS the value.

twist.text: Veblen was fired from multiple universities for sleeping with faculty wives.

climax.text: Veblen showed that consumption is social, not rational. We buy things to communicate who we are, not just what we need.

punchline.text: We buy expensive things to show we can afford to waste money.

quiz.question: What is conspicuous consumption according to Veblen?
options: Purchasing expensive goods primarily to display wealth and social status
